pr_title: KAFKA-9419: Integer Overflow Possible with CircularIterator

timeline.bodyText: Why change the logic since the answer is always true?
timeline.author: rondagostino

replies.author: belugabehr

replies.bodyText:
The constructor doesn't accept an empty list, but it doesn't copy it (or, better, if we were using persistent data structures... but alas no).  The class isn't thread-safe, and iterators that the code constructs and uses are potentially fail-safe or fail-fast if the collection is modified.  And the remove() method of this class throws UnsupportedOperationException.
All in all, I think the best thing is to clearly document that the class does not support modifications to the passed-in collection and always return true here (technically !isEmpty() covers all cases, but since the constructor doesn't accept an empty list the answer would always be true).
replies.author: rondagostino

timeline.bodyText: Should add that the class is not thread-safe.
timeline.author: rondagostino

timeline.bodyText: Need to add a test with a collection containing null -- this logic will break.  Best to always have the peek value, initializing it in the constructor.
timeline.author: rondagostino

timeline.bodyText: Should simply return true here, right?  As written now it is adjusting internal state, and it is best to isolate state manipulation to as few places as possible.
timeline.author: rondagostino

timeline.message: KAFKA-9419: Integer Overflow Possible with CircularIterator
Added JavaDoc. Support null values in the underlying collection
Always return true for hasNext(). Add more JavaDoc
Use an advance method to load next value and always return true in hasNext()
Use an advance method to load next value and always return true in hasNext()

timeline.bodyText: Could combine these into a single testCycleCollection() method if you put a null value in the list (e.g. "A", null, "C") and for every one of the 4 positions (0-2 and cycling back to 0) you also check the peek() value.  I think it would be clearer compared to what you have currently since the last 2 methods you have now are a bit haphazard.
timeline.author: rondagostino

timeline.bodyText:
no need to use this. outside the constructor.
Here and below
timeline.author: kkonstantine

timeline.bodyText: same comment on this. as above.
timeline.author: kkonstantine

timeline.bodyText: assertThrows is what we use for some time now, and it's available to the branches that this PR will be backported. (same below)
timeline.author: kkonstantine
